tr.td: KinOath Kinship Archiver is a professional scientific general kinship tool, and also an archive retrieval application. It is designed, first of all, to link kinship data with archived data such as, for example, media resources (i.e. audio files, video files, etc.). Secondly, being culturally nonspecific, this program makes it possible for users to create diagrams based on culturally, and therefore linguistically, different social structures. Such diagrams can then be compared and contrasted. A series of options are included which aim at optimizing graphical representation of the data, a key feature within KinOath environment.

chapter.title: How to run the application
chapter.para: KinOath Kinship Archiver is part of the Language Archiving Technology suite. You will find a link to the program on the TLA web page http://tla.mpi.nl/tools/tla-tools/kinoath.
You can start the application in two possible ways:

listitem.para: through the option Run via webstart (see figure below), with no installation needed;
through one of the installers provided. Installers are available for Windows, MacOS and Debian. See sections below for more detailed information.
Java. For more information on Java and how to install it go to http://java.com/en/.

section.title: Windows installer
section.para: To install the application on a computer with Windows as operating system:

listitem.para: Select Download the Windows installer (see figure above);
Choose Yes on the dialogue window which asks you to allow changes to the computer;
A setup wizards appears now: go through the several steps until when it says Install;
After installing click on Finish. If you want to run the application immediately after the installation, leave checked the option Launch KinOath Kinship Archiver.

section.title: Debian installer
section.para: To instal the application on a computer with Debian Linux as operating system:

listitem.para: Select Download the Debian Linux package;
Save the .deb file and then open it;
A window called Ubuntu Software Center will open. Select Install.

section.title: Mac installer
section.para: To instal the application on a computer with Macintosh as operating system:

listitem.para: Select Download the Mac installer;
Save the .tar file and then open it;
Click on the application icon that subsiquently appears;
A message may open asking you whether you want to open an application downloaded from the Internet. Select Open.

section.para: After you have selected the webstart, or installed the application, this is what you will see when opening KinOath Kinship Archiver:

chapter.title: Diagram types
chapter.para: The aim of this chapter is to explain:

para.emphasis: To create a standard diagram from scratch:

listitem.para: Open File menu > New Diagram of Type > Standard Diagram (database driven); a new page of the application will open.

Right click on the main white panel > Add > choose an item among the ones displayed (Individual, Chromosome_Example, Clan_Example, KinTerm, Social_Event), or among the ones listed in the profiles settings (Panels menu > Diagram Settings > Entity Profiles).
According to what you have chosen, a new entity will appear. Its icon shape depends on how this has been preconfigured in the profile settings (Panels menu > Diagram Settings > Symbol Fields).
Select the entity you have created. At the bottom of the page you will see a table with some information to fill in: name, gender, date of birth, date of death, etc.
Once you have entered the required information, either click on the entity or select Save all data changes from the right click menu. The entity should now show such infomation.

note.para: As far as kinship data are concerned, you can:

listitem.para: add custom fields. Right click on the table and choose the one(s) you need from the list. Alternatively, you can type the field by yourself, using the option Add <custom field> (again, via right click menu).
delete custom fields. Select the field you want to delete > right click > Delete field "...".
decide which custom fields need to be shown on the diagram next to the entity. To do so:
Panels menu > Diagram settings > Label fields tab;
Select the field you want to be shown on diagram and drag it to the Label fields tab on top of the page. Or choose the field from the drop down menu located into the mentioned tab, and click on Add.
By contrast, to delete fields, click on the small squares on the right of the tab (see red arrow in the figure below).
Once that several, single entities have been created, you may also want to create relations between them. To do so:

select how many entities you need (click on them while holding down the SHIFT key on the keyboard) and right click. You can choose between: sibling, ancestor, descendant, union, kinterm, other (the latter meaning that the relation connecting two, or more, entities, is not a sanguine relation, but it has to do with other kinds of relationships), directedin (a relation from one specific entity), directedout (a relation to one specific entity), undirected (a bidirectional relation).

note.para: as far as ancestor and descendant are concerned, the choice of one or the other depends on which entity you select first. In other words: if you select the parent first, then you have to use the descendant relation, whereas if you select the child first, you will have to choose the ancestor relation.

listitem.para: Alternatively, you can simply select one entity, take the little blue circle you need, and drag it to the other entity (see figure below).
When you create an egocentric diagram, you may want to set one of the entities present on it as the its "starting point". To do so:
select the entity you want to set as ego > right click > choose Set as Ego (list will be cleared). That entity will go black.

The text into brackets (list will be cleared) means that a diagram can only have one ego. The moment you try to set a second ego, the other one will return a normal entity again. One excludes the other.
However, if you have several diagrams, you can set several egos: select the entity > right click > Add to ego list.
To remove relations between entities:
select the necessary entities (click on them while holding down the SHIFT key on the keyboard) and right click. From the menu coming out choose Remove Relations > Remove relations between selected.
To delete/remove entities:
select the necessary entity > right click > Delete. The entity is deleted from the database and from all diagrams.
select the necessary entity > right click > Release from diagram. The entity is removed from the diagram, but in this case it remains in the database, unlike with the option Delete, just described.
Relations between entities can be personalized through a series of graphical options. To customize such relations:
Panels menu > Diagram settings > Relation Type Definitions tab. This tab, in turn, is made up of sub-tabs:
Custom Name: a free text field to make the relation more specific;
Data Category: the data can have an ISOcat link;
Relation Type: you can choose among the types seen above (sibling, union, etc.);
Line Colour: you can set a different colour for each one of the different relation lines;
Line Width: the relation lines can be thicker or thinner;
Curve Line Orientation: you can choose between horizontal and vertical orientation. This option, however, is not valid for sanguine relations lines.
Look at the figure below to see how these features work.
To link some archive data to your kinship data (the main function of KinOath Kinship Archiver):

Panels menu > Archive Linker. A panel will open on the right of the page, called The TLA Language Archiver (if you have been using Arbil, then two other tabs may also open in the same panel: Arbil Remote Corpus and Arbil Local Corpus).

Choose the resource you need from the tree and drag it to the corresponding entity in the Diagram Tree tab that you can see on the left of the page. The archive reference will be shown next to the entity. See figure below. The numbers point out how many references have been linked.
To save the diagram you have created:
File menu > Save as > choose a directory and a file name.
Besides the normal saving process, you have other options you can choose from in File menu:

Export as PDF/JPEG/PNG/TIFF: this option allows you to export files (in one of the following formats: PDF, JPEG, PNG and TIFF) to a directory in your computer. As in the previous option, Save as, when selecting Export as ... you will be asked to choose a directory and a file name plus, in this case, a file format.
Export for R / SPSS: this option allows you to export a KinOath diagram to either R or SPSS, two programs you can mainly use to statistically analyse your data. The file format is, by deafult, .tab.

note.para: The file you have saved, or exported, is also visible on a web page. You only have to take it from the directory and drag it into a web browser.
Once the diagram is open on a web page, the archive links possibly existing become hyperlinks. If you select them you will be redirected to their corresponding location on the IMDI Browser tree.

listitem.para: To close the application:
File menu > Close (name of the diagram).
File menu > Exit.

para.emphasis: To create/modify a standard diagram starting from already existing entities that need to be searched for into the database:

listitem.para: First of all, you have to import data. To do so:

otherwise, if you want to become more familiar with the application, you can use the sample data contained into the application itself: File menu > Import Sample Data > choose the data you want to import.

when you start the import, a window like the one below appears. Select Start Import. Once the process has finished, select Close. The entities will be now listed in the Project Tree tab on the left of the page.

Now open the Search Entities tab on the left of the page and enter the name of the entity you want to search for. Press Enter, or click on Search. All the entities somehow related to your search will be listed in the same tab.
Entities can also be searched with fuzzy matching, so that possible spelling mistakes will not interfere with the search.
The results can also be expanded through kin type strings. To do so:
check the option Expand selection by kin type string.

in the white field located below the just mentioned option enter the necessary kin type strings (you can find a list of the main kin type strings in section 2.2 below). As you enter different strings, the diagram updates itself accordingly.

section.title: Freeform Diagram (transient)
section.para: To create a freeform diagram:

listitem.para: File menu > New Diagram of Type > Freeform Diagram (transient); a new page of the application will open. On top of this page you will see a white panel called Kin Type Strings, from which you will create your diagram.
Here is a list of the main kyn type strings. A more detailed list can be found through the path: Panels menu > Diagram Settings > Kin Type Definitions:
E = ego; Ef= female ego; Em = male ego; x = undefined
F or Fa = father; M or Mo = mother; P or Pa = parent
B or Br = brother; Z or Si = sister; Sb = sibling
S or So = son; D or Da = daughter; C or Ch = child
H or Hu = husband; W or Wi = wife; So = spouse
* = first-degree relatives
As you enter the necessary strings into the panel you will see your diagram take form.
Besides the mere kin type definitions, however, you can also add labels to the entities, such as names and dates. To do so:
you first have to enter a colon after the kin type definition and then the label(s);
different labels belonging to the same entity need to be separated by a semi-colon;
another colon goes after the last label and before the (if any) following kin type definition.
labels need to be entered in a fixed order, which is:

Id: an Id is added when the same kin type definition is used for different entities, so that you are able to distinguish them; it is represented by a #-sign followed by a number. So, for example, if you have two male egos, one will be simply Em, and the other Em:#1.
You can decide whether to show or hide the Ids. To show them: Diagram Options > check the item Show Id Labels. Leave it unchecked to hide them.
The application also contains a sample freeform diagram. To open it:
File menu > Open Sample Diagram > Freeform Diagram Syntax.
If you want to modify such diagram, you can:
click on the main panel of the page > a message will come out: The diagram needs to be recalculated before it can be interacted with. Recalculate now? > OK.
Edit menu > Recalculate the Diagram.
To save the diagram: see Section 2.1, point 6.

section.title: Kin Terms Diagram
section.para: To create a kin terms diagram:

listitem.para: File menu > New Diagram of Type > Kin Terms Diagram; a new page of the application will open. On the right of the page you will see a panel called Kin Term Group (unnamed), from which you will create your diagram.
In the white string located on top of the panel you can enter the name of your diagram;
The panel contains a table with some information to fill in:
Description: here you explain your kin terms; for example, you can add an English gloss if the kin terms entered are in another language.
You can also have several kin term groups for the same diagram.
To add other groups: Kin Terms menu > New Kin Term Group. A new tab (the same as the one described above) will appear. The information to fill in is the same as before.
In the figure below you can see a sample kin terms diagram with two kin term groups:

note.para: Besides Japanese Kin Terms, the application contains two other sample diagrams of this kind: Hawaiian Kin Terms, and Swedish Kin Terms, reachable via File menu > Open Sample Diagram.

listitem.para: to show or hide the kin terms on the diagram > respectively check or uncheck the option Show on graph. It is checked by default;
Kin Term diagrams can also be either imported or exported through the options Import/Export from the Kin Terms panel (see section 2.4 below).
To save the diagram: see Section 2.1, point 6.
You can also save/export the kin terms diagram you have created via Kin Terms menu > Export > choose a file name and a directory > Save.

If you then want to re-open the diagram: Kin Terms menu > Import > choose the file you want to import > Open > the diagram will open, together with a message telling you how many entities have been imported.

section.title: Query Diagram
section.para: To create a query diagram:

listitem.para: File menu > New Diagram of Type > Query Diagram; a new page of the application will open, with some previously seen panels: Diagram Tree, Project Tree (on the left), Kin Type Strings (on top).
This type of diagram allows you to search for entities within the entire KinOath Kinship Archiver database.
You can make your query in two ways:
you can use the kin type definitions seen above with the freeform diagram, together with labels (names, dates, etc.). See the example below:
The entities you have searched for are now listed in the Diagram Tree tab.
you can make your query even detailed:
Panels menu > check the item Search Entities > the tab will appear next to Diagram Tree and Project Tree tabs.
Enter the name of the entity you want to find into the white string > press Enter or click on Search > all the entities somehow related to your query will be there listed.

Take the specific entity you are looking for and drag it to the Kin Type Strings panel, preceded by the E of ego. This will appear on the main panel. Add other kin strings if you want to modify your query.
To save the diagram: see Section 2.1, point 6.

note.para: The application contains a sample query diagram, named Query Diagram Syntax, reachable via File menu > Open Sample Diagram.

section.para: The first menu available is the File menu (see figure above), which includes the following options:

listitem.para: New (default diagram): this option allows you to open a new diagram. It says default diagram because when KinOath opens, it shows the diagram that was previously set as default through the option Set Default Diagram as (see below).

Open Diagram: this option allows you to open a diagram choosing from the ones present in your computer directories. Once you have selected the file you need, and clicked Open, the file will open in a new page of KinOath.

Open Recent Diagram: through this option you can select and re-open one of the diagrams which were previously opened. If you want to delete the list of diagrams opened you can select Clear list (it is located at the bottom of the list).

Import Gedcom / CSV / TIP File: this option allows you to import kinship files in either Gedcom, CSV, or TIP format. Once it is selected, a window will open asking you to choose the file to import from a directory. The file selected will then open in a new page of KinOath.

Set Default Diagram as: through this option you can take a certain type of diagram and some diagram settings, and set them as default, so that when you start the application again, this will open showing the specific diagram and settings you preconfigured.

Add Geometry: its sub-options are: Add Label, Add Circle, Add Square, and Add Ellipse. The first one (Add Label) allows you to enter a label for your diagram, and you can do it by entering the text into a small window opening at the bottom of the page when the option is selected. The other three (Add Circle, Add Square, Add Ellipse) are graphic options you can use to differentiate kin groups.

Merge Selected Entities: you can use this option when, for example, you have two separate entities carrying different pieces of information but you find them to be the same individual, and therefore you want to make them merge into a single entity. What results from the merger is a single individual carrying the information of the two merged entities. [Note: at the moment it only merges the entities but not the kinship data that such entities carry]
Duplicate Selected Entities: when choosing this option, the entity/ies previously selected will be doubled.
Remove from ego list: through this option you can move entities from the "Ego" list back to the "Required" list.
Keep on diagram: with this option you decide to keep the selected entity/ies on the diagram and, therefore, make it/them permanent diagram entities (see the note below).
Reset Zoom: when selecting this option the zoom of the diagram returns back to its default size.

Reset Layout: it can happen, when you select many entities at a time to put into in the diagram, that they overlap and you cannot see them clearly. By resetting the layout, such entities are distanced from each other.

note.para: You will have to bear in mind the distinction between permanent and temporary entities, i.e. between those which are stored on the diagram when this is saved (the former), and those which, by contrast, go away once the diagram has been saved, but still remain in the database (the latter). This distinction is marked through the COLOUR of the entities: black for the permanent ones, grey for the temporary ones. In order to make entities go black you have to choose the item Keep on diagram mentioned above. In addition, the same differentiation will appear in the Diagram Tree tab located on the left of the page (see figure below): all the permanent entities will be shown under Implied, whereas the temporary ones will go under Required. Newly created entities are, by contrast, black by default.

section.title: Sample Diagrams
section.para: Apart from the possibility to work on new diagrams, KinOath includes also a list of sample diagrams that are useful to observe and to get to know the program and its functionalities, and that can be opened through the option "Open Sample Diagram" from the File menu. These are: Freeform Diagram Syntax, Query Diagram Syntax, Hawaiian Kin Terms, Japanese Kin Terms, Swedish Kin Terms, Named Transient Entities, Matrimonial Ring Examples, Charles II of Spain, and Haemophilia in European Royalty.

note.para: Some hints: press alt + rotate the mouse wheel to zoom the diagram; press shift + rotate the mouse wheel to pan the diagram to the right or to the left; just rotate the mouse wheel to scroll the diagram up or down.

section.title: Edit menu
section.para: This menu contains options related to the modification of a diagram:

listitem.para: Select All: by clicking on this option all the entities of all the diagrams present in the central panel will be highlighted (i.e. they will be sorrounded by a blue, dotted line).
Select Related: if you select one entity and then choose this option, all the entities somehow related to the one selected will be hightlighted.
Expand Selection: if you select one entity and then choose this option, only the entities immediately related to the one selected will be highlighted.
Deselect All: this option is for deselecting the entities, or the relations between entities, which were previously selected.

Recalculate the Diagram: this option allows you to partially modify, or totally recreate, a diagram. Once selected you are allowed to add: new entities (in the standard diagram), new constraints to new or already existing entities (in the freeform and in the query diagrams), new kin terms and kin groups (in the kin terms, but also in the freeform, diagram). Alternatively, you can simply click on the diagram and the following message will come out: "The diagram needs to be recalculated before it can be interacted with. recalculate now?"

section.title: Diagram Options menu
section.para: This menu contains options related to the layout of a diagram. They only have to be checked or unchecked according to the needs.

listitem.para: Snap To Grid: this option is checked by default, and it allows you to move the entities only in certain ways, as if an imaginary grid was there, and the sanguine lines could be placed only on the grid. If unchecked, you can move the entities as you want, with no "grid restriction".
Highlight Selected Relations: if this option is checked, when you select one entity, the relations that this one has with other, immediately close, entities will be highlighted in blue.
Show Diagram Border: if this option is checked, you can see the border of the diagram (a grey line).
Show Sanguin Lines: if this option is unchecked, the lines connecting one entity to the other disappear.
Show Labels: if this option is unchecked, the labels (names for example) added to the individuals when creating the diagram disappear.
Show Kin Type Labels: if this option is unchecked, the kin type definitions next to the labels ("EfM" for example) disappear.
Show Id Labels:

Show Date Labels: when you create individuals you can also enter, besides name and gender, a date of birth and of death. You may decide not to show such dates; if you want them hidden you have to leave this option unchecked.

Show Archive Links: this option is valid for the diagram type "Archive Data Linker" and for the Gedcom imports that have resources. In both cases, the entities that are placed into the diagram will carry a label of the type: "archive ref.: 1, 2, etc." (see figure below). Such label disappears if this option is unchecked.

section.title: Kin Terms menu
section.para: The whole menu is available only for the Kin Terms Diagram, whereas in the other cases only the option New Kin Term Group can be accessed. This menu includes the following options:

listitem.para: Show: this option allows you to see the kin terms panel on the right of the page. If you uncheck it, the panel disappears and all the other menu options are not available anymore.

Import: instead of creating a new kin term group from scratch you may decide to import an already existing one from a file directory in your computer. To do so, click on Import and choose the file you want to import. The kin terms imported will be added to the ones in the table in the right panel and also in the diagram (if a diagram has already been created, otherwise they will go and create a new one themselves).

section.title: Panels menu
section.para: This menu contains a list of all the panels that can be opened while working on a diagram (some of them have already been mentioned when describing the diagram types). You can choose which ones you want to open simply by checking them.

listitem.para: Active Plugins: this option becomes visible only whether, and when, there are, effectively, plugins.
Archive Linker: by choosing this option a panel will open on the right of the page displaying the entire IMDI corpora. [Note: at the moment this panel is not available. See appendix below]
Diagram Settings: by choosing this option a panel will open on the top of the page with some tabs:

Entity Profiles: this tab includes a list of profiles which can be added or removed when creating the individuals going into a diagram. They just need to be checked and/or unchecked. See figure above.

Kin Type Definitions: this tab includes a list of the main kin type strings with their corresponding definitions (which have also been described in this manual in section 2.1.1, "Freeform Diagram" paragraph). You can delete elements of the list by checking them and then clicking on the option Delete Selected on the right of the page.

Besides, you may want to add new kin types to the list. Bear in mind though, that a new kin type added to a standard diagram behaves differently from a new kin type added to a freeform diagram. Let's make an example:
Kin Type String: Q
Relation Type: sibling
Symbol Type: triangle, circle

As far as a standard diagram is concerned, the new kin type represents a filter, which means that when I look up an entity, e.g. Albert_Iof_Monaco, and use the 'Q' kin type, in the central panel I will see the entity searched for, plus all those other individuals (both male and female given the previously set symbol types) carrying a sibling-relation type with it. To put it simply, I will see Albert_Iof_Monaco and his, possibly existing, brother/s and sister/s.

By contrast, in the case of a freeform diagram, what the new kin type does is creating new entities from scratch. In other words, if in the Kin Type Strings panel I type, for example, 'EfQ', in the central panel I will see a female ego which is the - so to speak - reference point of my diagram, together with a brother (sibling relation + triangle) and a sister (sibling relation + circle).

Label Fields: this tab contains some information about the entities created by the user (we are referring to the "Standard Diagram (database driven)" type), i.e. name, date of birth, etc. It may be the case that not all of the fields contained in the table at the bottom of the page, and related to the entity selected, are also shown at the top of the page, i.e. they may not be visible on the diagram. In order to make them appear on the diagram next to the entity, you have to search for them in the drop down menu and click on Add (see figure below). You can delete the labels by clicking on the small squares on the right of the tab (see red arrow). However, they still remain in the table at the bottom of the page, so if you want to add them back to the panel on the top you just need to take them, one at a time, and drag them to the string of the drop down menu.

Relation Type Definitions: through this tab you can add details to the relations between the entities. It has some sub-tabs: Custom Name, Data Category, Relation Type (which, in turn, lets you choose among sibling, ancestor (descendant), descendant (ancestor), union, kinterm, other, undirected, directedin (directedout), directedout (directedin), <any>); Line Colour; Line Width, Line/Dash, Curve Line Orientation. Look at the picture below to see how they work.

Symbol Fields: according to the features that are attributed to the entities, these get different shapes, for example a female ego is a circle, whereas a male ego is a triangle. Such shapes, however, can be modified by choosing among the possibilities included in the drop down lists on the right of the panel.

note.para: Not all of the options just explained are available for all the diagram types. They vary according the diagram type and, therefore, according to the diagram purposes.

listitem.para: Diagram Tree: this panel opens up on the left of the page. It displays three possible lists: Ego, Required, Implied.

When you create new individuals, they automatically go under the "Required" list. If you want an egocentric diagram, you have to add an ego (or several egos if you want to create several diagrams), to the "Ego" list (right click on the entity > Set as Ego (list will be cleared)). The ego added to the list goes black and represents the reference point of your diagram.

By comparison, when you search for an already existing entity, you will see the ego of your diagram under the Ego list and, on the other hand, under the "Implied" list, there will be all those entities that are automatically linked to the one selected. See figure below.
Kin Terms: this panel opens up automatically when working on a "Kin Terms" diagram (see section 2.4).

Kin Type Strings: this panel opens up automatically in case of a freeform or a query diagram. In it you type the strings necessary to create new individuals (freeform diagram) or to look for them (query diagram). (see section 2.1.1 above, Freeform Diagram paragraph)

Search Entities: this option is available for the standard and the query diagram, which are both database driven. Indeed, its function is to search for specific entities in the database. To do so, you have to type the name of the entity in the white string included in this tab and press "Enter", or click on Search. You can also search for related entities by checking the option Expand Selection by Kin Type String and by entering a kin type definition of the type seen before. (see figure below)

section.title: Plugins menu
section.para: This menu simply shows you which plugins are active on the application in that ongoing session. If no plugins are present, then you will only see: <no plugins found>. This structure provides KinOath Kinship Archiver with even more flexibility, and makes it possible for third parties to develop new application features.

section.title: Window menu
section.para: The options of this menu vary according to how many windows of KinOath have been opened. Indeed, it simply consists of a list of the options that have been selected and opened: sample diagrams, new diagrams, etc. Each window has its corresponding menu option checked.

section.title: Help menu
section.para: This menu includes some additional information about the program:

listitem.para: About: by selecting this option a dialog window will open, briefly describing the program.
Internal Help: it opens the instructions manual onto a new page of the application.
KinOath Website: it redirects you to the web page of the application (http://tla.mpi.nl/tools/tla-tools/kinoath).
KinOath Online Manual: it links you to the online version of the manual, located on the TLA webpage (http://www.mpi.nl/corpus/html/kinoath/index.html)

KinOath Forum (Website): by selecting this option you will be redirected to the following page: http://tla.mpi.nl/forums/software/kinoath, a discussion board page where you can start discussions about topics relevant to KinOath Kinship Archiver.
View Error Log: by selecting this option a page in NotePad will open, containing the possible errors encountered while using the program.

Reindex all files: this option may turn out useful when, for example, somebody has modified your data on a file hosting service (such as Dropbox) and you have to synchronize these modified files with the ones present on the disk. It may not be necessary, though, to manually select this option, because the files will be reindexed automatically.
Check for Updates: this option allows you to search for more recent versions of KinOath Kinship Archiver.

chapter.title: How to...?
chapter.para: This chapter is aimed at summarizing the main content of the manual in a practical way. To put it differently, here you will find straightforward instructions that will help you become a bit more familiar with the application.

section.title: ...add entities via right click menu
section.para: There exist two possible ways of adding new entities to your - standard type - diagram. The first one is the following:

listitem.para: Point the mouse inside the main, white panel and right click. Select the first item of the menu: Add, and then one of the five items that come up: Individual, Chromosome_Example, Clan_Example, KinTerm, Social_Event. Regardless of which one you choose, an entity represented by a small square will appear in the main panel.

Select the just mentioned item; a table at the bottom of the page will open with several fields to fill in. The fields vary for the different entity profiles mentioned in the previous point. Once you have entered the required information click again on the entity, it will change accordingly (e.g. depending on its gender the square will turn into a circle or a triangle).

section.title: ...add/remove relations
section.para: After creating a certain amount of entities you may want to create also relations between them. To do so:

listitem.para: Select the two, or more, entities you need (SHIFT key being hold down); right click; choose the menu item Add relation, and then select the type of relation you want. The entities will be linked accordingly.

As for the relation types ancestor and descendant, remember that: if you select first the ancestor, and then the descendant, you have to choose a descendant relation type. By comparison, if you do it the other way round, i.e. first descendant and then ancestor, you have to choose an ancestor relation type.

If you decide to remove some of the relations just created, select again how many entities you need (SHIFT key being hold down) and right click; choose the menu item Remove Relations and then Remove relations between selected. The line linking the entities will go away.

section.title: ...release VS delete entities
section.para: There are two options through which you can remove entities from your diagram:

listitem.para: Delete: the delete option will remove an entity from all the diagrams, and also from the database. Once you select it (select the entity/ies you want to remove and right click) a message will pop up telling you that a number of entities will be deleted from the database.
Release from diagram: this option (select the needed entity/ies > right click) will simply remove an entity from the diagram, but unlike 'delete' it will not remove it from the database.

section.title: ...add entities via search tab
section.para: The second way to add entities to your diagram is through the Search Entities tab:

listitem.para: Follow the same steps explained in section 3.1, i.e. [If you do not already have a project-based diagram open (see section 2.1 above - option 'Open Diagram')] File menu > New Diagram of Type > Standard diagram (database driven).

On the left of the page select the tab Search Entities. In the white field under Search Entity Names type the name of an entity that you know is present in the database; then click Search. In the white column under 'Search' you will see a list of all the entities (partially) matching your query.

The option Graph selection (below the 'Search Entity Names' white field) is checked by default; this means that when you select an entity from the list given to you after the query is made, this will automatically appear in the main panel. If you uncheck this option, you will have to manually drag the selected entity to the main panel.

Another option that may turn useful is Expand selection by kin type string (below 'Graph selection'). If you check it, and then enter some kin types in the white field below it, you will see the previously selected entity changing accordingly. E.g. (after having imported the sample data 'European Royalty') type 'Albert' and then click 'Search'. Select one of the entities that appear in the list: it will appear also in the main panel. Then check the field 'Expand selection...' and type '*'. All (if any) first-degree relatives related to the entity selected will appear on the diagram as well.

section.title: ...create a freeform diagram
section.para: The instructions given above applied to the diagram type standard - database driven. This section, by comparison, is about another diagram type: the freeform diagram. Here is how it works:

listitem.para: [If you do not already have a project-based diagram open (see section 2.1 above - option 'Open Diagram')] From the File menu select New Diagram of Type and then Freeform Diagram (transient).
In the tab on top of the page - Kin Type Strings - type the strings with which you want to create your diagram. A list of the main kin types is given in section 2.1.1 above.

To the kin types you can attach some labels, namely names, dates, etc. To do so, enter a colon after the kin type, then separate each of the label with a semi-colon, and finally enter another colon between the last label and the next kin type. The labels have to be entered with a precise order: Id [mind that the Id is normally used when you have two entities with the same kin type definition], name, date of birth - date of death. E.g. Ef:Jane;1950-2010:M:Carla;1925-2000:.....

[If you do not already have a project-based diagram open (see section 2.1 above - option 'Open Diagram')] From the File menu, select New Diagram of Type and then Query Diagram. As the name says, this diagram is mainly used when you want to search for entities within the ones present in the database.
What you can do here is either type something for yourself, or directly use the entities in the tab Project Tree on the left of the page.

In the first case, you can type something like 'x[Albert_I]' in the tab 'Kin Type Strings' on top of the page: in the main panel you will see all the entities named Albert_I and/or containing Albert_I in their names. Besides, you can add futher kin types like 'x[Albert_I]*', in which case you will see all the possibly existing first-degree relatives of all the entities present in the main panel.

In the second case, by comparison, you can select an entity in particular from the 'Project Tree' tab and drag it to the Kin Type Strings tab on top of the page, preceded either by E or x, which stand for any, unspecified entity [note that if you want to narrow the field of search you can always open the 'Search Entities' tab via 'Panels' menu]. E.g. x[Entity.Identifier=7bd7bff7-ff5e-4424-a9c9-d1283e0df145]; in the main panel you will see only that entity in particular. As in the previous case, you can also add further kin types, and the diagram in the main panel will change accordingly.
[If you do not already have a project-based diagram open (see section 2.1 above - option 'Open Diagram')] From the File menu, select New Diagram of Type and Kin Terms Diagram.

In the tab on the right of the page, fill in the table (for the moment you can skip Propositus Kin Type Strings). The header Kin Term is quite straightforward: enter the kin terms; under the header Referent Kin Type Strings enter the kin types corresponding to the kin terms previously written; under Description you can put, for example, the English gloss of the kin terms (if these are in a different language).
E.g.: Italian kin terms
Kin Term - padre; Referent Kin Type Strings - EF; Description: father
K.T. - madre; R.K.T.S. - EM; D. - mother
K.T. - fratello; R.K.T.S. - EB; D. - brother
K.T. - sorella; R.K.T.S. - EZ; D. - sister
etc. The diagram will grow as you add kin terms.

If you want to create a new kin term group [take Japanese Kin Terms sample diagram as reference: File > Open Sample Diagram > Japanese Kin Terms] go to Kin Terms menu on top of the page and select New Kin Term Group. A second tab will open on the right of the page. It is of the same type as the one you already used and the table in it needs to be filled in the same way (choose a different color so that the two kin term groups can be easily distinguished).

Two functions that you may use while working on a kin terms diagram are: a) importing previously created and saved kin terms; b) exporting the ones you have just created. As for the former, go to Kin Terms menu and select Import. A window will open asking you to choose a file. Choose the one you need and select Open. The kin terms will appear both in the table on the right of the page and in the main panel in the form of diagram. Besides, another window popping up will tell you how many kin terms have been imported. As for exporting, select the option Export from the Kin Terms menu. A window will open asking you to choose a directory where to export the kin terms and a file name; then select Save. The kin terms will be exported to the chosen directory.

Finally, there are two more options you can use: 1) Show on graph. It is checked by default, which implies that you are able to see the actual kin terms. If you unckeck it, the kin terms will be removed from the diagram but kept in the table. 2) Generate Example Entities. It is checked by default as well, and it allows you to see the diagram developing and growing as you enter new kin terms. If you uncheck it, the whole diagram will go away (but the kin terms, like in the previous case, are kept in the table).

appendix.title: Features not available in KinOath 1.2

note.para: As you may have noticed, KinOath 1.2 presents some hidden options. These features are not implemented at the moment, but will be available in the next releases of the application. However, they are already available in the current testing version.

listitem.para: Add Polyline (Standard Diagram > right click menu > Add Geometry);
Delete Group ((File menu > New Diagram of Type > Kin Terms Diagram > panel on the right of the page);
Archive Data Linker diagram (File menu > New Diagram of Type > Archive Data Linker);
Archive Linker menu (top of the page).

appendix.para: For further information on KinOath Kinship Archiver, please refer to the following links:

http://tla.mpi.nl/tools/tla-tools/kinoath/requests/; on this page you will find a list of already known issues about KinOath 1.2, and of some feature requests which will be possibly implemented in the future versions of the application.
http://tla.mpi.nl/tools/tla-tools/kinoath/changes/; on this page, by contrast, you will see a list showing which changes have been made to which version of the application.
